chapter.title: 131 Lagenidium, Paralagenidium, Pythium, Rhinosporidium, and Uncultivated Paracoccidioides Species (Formerly Lacazia loboi)

sect1.title: 131 Lagenidium, Paralagenidium, Pythium, Rhinosporidium, and Uncultivated Paracoccidioides Species (Formerly Lacazia loboi)
sect1.para: RAQUEL VILELA AND LEONEL MENDOZA

In the past 100 years, the microbial pathogens described in this chapter have been classified as fungal and/or parafungal protistan microbes (1–4). Based on their apparent epidemiological connection with water, they were at one point also placed in a new category of hydrophilic infectious agents (1). However, based on taxonomic and other morphological characteristics, these four anomalous species, Lagenidium, Pythium, Rhinosporidium, and the uncultivated fungus previously known as Lacazia loboi, were not well understood (1, 4). This frustrating situation fueled a strong controversy that has only recently been solved with the advent of molecular methodologies (5, 6). Despite the recent finding that both Pythium insidiosum and Rhinosporidium seeberi are protistan pathogens, they are still studied by medical mycologists, continuing a historical tradition. The finding of two members of the Oomycota (generically referred as the oomycetes) affecting mammalian hosts, Lagenidium and Paralagenidium, alerted the medical community to the presence of a novel group of primary Oomycota pathogens phenotypically like the fungi and indistinguishable from the clinical and pathological features displayed by P. insidiosum during infection. In addition, Vilela et al. (7, 8) recently reported that the uncultivated fungus developing skin granulomas in dolphin and humans, long believed to be Lacazia loboi, comprised two different Paracoccidioides species: P. ceti and P. loboi. Based on ribosomal DNA (rDNA) phylogenetic analysis, the evolutionary location of the microbial pathogens discussed in this chapter is illustrated in Fig. 1. Table 1 summarizes the most prominent features of the pathogens covered in this section.

sect1.title: Taxonomy
sect1.para: Jorge de Oliveira Lobo first described parakeloidal skin lesions (Jorge Lobo’s disease) in a patient from the state of Pernambuco, Brazil, in 1930 (9). He stated that the new pathogen was phenotypically similar to the parasitic stages of the genera Blastomyces and Paracoccidioides. The earliest attempts to isolate this pathogen in culture met with failure, and soon it became clear that this pathogen resists culture (4, 10). This fact led to great controversy regarding its epidemiological and taxonomic affinities, reflected by the numerous names under which this pathogen was known. In 1999, Taborda et al. (11) suggested the binomial Lacazia loboi to end more than 70 years of taxonomic ambiguity. Based on this proposal, Vilela et al. (12) suggested the disease name “lacaziosis,” but with the placement of these uncultivated species within the genus Paracoccidioides, the term became obsolete (7, 8). Likewise, the disease name ‘‘lobomycosis” has long been questioned because it derives from the obsolete genus Lobomyces (4). Initial phylogenetic studies placed L. loboi as the sister taxon to Paracoccidioides brasiliensis (5, 13, 14), but besides the long branches described in phylogenetic analyses of these pathogens, there were not sufficient DNA sequences to support this claim. Vilela et al. (15), using at least five different PCR amplified genes (chitin synthase 4, ADP-ribosylation factor, gp43, Kex, and ITS rDNA) from DNA extracted directly from 20 L. loboi human specimens, presented a strong argument for the phylogenetic placement of this pathogen as an independent taxon. However, no DNA sequences from infected dolphins were included in their analyses.

The first case of dolphin skin disease with yeastlike cells was reported in 1971 (16). Based on clinical, histopathological, and serological analyses and the uncultivated nature of the pathogen, it was long believed to be the same as L. loboi in humans (4, 7). However, recent molecular data using DNA sequences (Gp43 and ITS rDNA) from different dolphins (17–19) clustered their DNA with the DNA sequences of cultivated Paracoccidioides species causing systemic infection in humans. A recent phylogenetic study with DNA sequences (Gp43, Kex, and ITS rDNA) of six dolphins in the United States with granulomas and yeastlike cells confirmed previous reports (7). These studies revealed that the interrogated dolphin DNA sequences, including those used in early analyses, clustered among the cultivated human P. brasiliensis isolates. Interestingly, the inclusion of dolphin DNA sequences lowers the bootstrap support of human L. loboi DNA sequences as an independent species from the genus Paracoccidioides. Vilela et al. (7) argued that, as was previously suspected (4), perhaps the genus Lacazia is a Paracoccidioides species. Because few DNA sequences from dolphins with the disease were used in phylogenetic analysis, the separation of the dolphin DNA from the cultivated Paracoccidioides species remained a puzzle. Meanwhile, Vilela and Mendoza (20) proposed the variety P. brasiliensis var. ceti and the disease name “paracoccidioidomycosis ceti” until its position in the tree of life was elucidated (7).

figure.title: FIGURE 1 Phylogenetic location of the four groups of microbial pathogens studied in this chapter (based on small-subunit ribosomal DNA sequences). Forming a sister group, the Algae (Archaeplastida) and Stramenopiles (SAR) are placed basal to the plants (30). The latter includes the mammalian pathogenic Oomycota Pythium spp., Lagenidium spp., and Paralagenidium spp. They develop hypha-like elements, vesicles with biflagellate zoospores, and oogonia. R. seeberi is placed within the Opisthokonta, at the point where the Metazoa (animals) and Fungi diverge (red circle). This uncultivated protist is characterized by the development of spherical phenotypes with endoconidia. The uncultivated Paracoccidioides ceti, causing infections in dolphins, and P. loboi, pathogenic for humans, are anomalous ascomycetous fungi that develop yeastlike cells in chains.

sect1.para: More recently, Vilela et al. (8), investigating several dolphin ITS rDNA and protein coding genes (chitin synthase 4, ADP-ribosylation factor, gp43, Kex, and ITS rDNA) in population genetic and other analyses, found that the DNA sequences of the uncultivated dolphin pathogen formed a monophyletic cluster within the cultivated P. americana and P. brasiliensis, and separated from the uncultivated skin pathogen of humans known as L. loboi. Based on these analyses, they proposed the binomial P. ceti for the dolphin skin pathogen first described by Migaki et al. (16) and emended the binomial P. loboi for the human disease described by Jorge Lobo in 1930 (9). Under this new nomenclature, the use of the name “Jorge Lobo’s disease” for human cases of skin infection, and “paracoccidioidomycosis ceti” for skin-infected dolphins, was proposed (8, 20). They also recommended, along with Jorge Lobo’s disease, the name “paracoccidioidomycosis loboi” to differentiate the disease name of this uncultivated pathogen from the human-cultivated Paracoccidioides species, traditionally labeled as “paracoccidioidomycosis” (Table 1). The analysis of more DNA sequences and perhaps the complete genomes of both pathogens of humans and dolphins will reveal more insights into the evolutionary paths of these two neglected uncultivated Paracoccidioides species.

sect1.title: Description of the Agent
sect1.para: BecauseP. ceti and P. loboi cannot be cultured, our knowledge of these pathogens is based on the morphological features observed in their parasitic stage. The in vivo phenotype is characterized by the development of comparable unicellular, thick-walled, lemon-shaped yeastlike cells found forming long chains of one, two, or more cells with occasional branching and characteristically connected by short tubules, a feature usually absent in yeast cells of cultivated Paracoccidioides species (Fig. 2B and C). The yeastlike cells of P. ceti and P. loboi measure ~5 to ~12 μm in diameter and can be easily observed with most stains. Interestingly, the in vivo phenotype of both pathogens shows multiple budding cells around the mother yeast cell, resembling the parasitic stage of the cultivated Paracoccidioides species, a finding consistent with current phylogenetic classification (Fig. 2B) (7, 8). The phenotypic features of P. loboi and the cross-reaction observed in serological tests of patient sera with skin infection and the antigens of P. brasiliensis led Lacaz et al. (4) in 1948 to classify this pathogen as Paracoccidioides loboi. Electron microscopic analysis of P. loboi showed thick chitinous yeastlike cell walls and an amorphous cytoplasmic content (4). Approximately 60% of the yeastlike cells observed lacked a defined cytoplasmic region, a finding in agreement with the result of viability studies.

sect1.title: Epidemiology and Transmission
sect1.para: Jorge Lobo’s disease is known to occur in human patients inhabiting the tropical areas of Latin America (4, 9). Although most humans with skin disease have been from Brazil, cases from Mexico, Central America, Colombia, Suriname, Venezuela, and other nearby countries have also been reported (4). American and Canadian patients were reported with the infection after visiting or working in areas of endemicity in Latin America (21, 22). Interestingly, a putative case of Jorge Lobo’s disease in a Greek woman with no history of traveling to the Americas was recently reported (23). The diagnosis was based on histological morphology. However, the yeastlike cells observed in this patient lacked some of the morphological features observed in Fig. 2A through C. Moreover, no molecular testing was conducted to further authenticate the case. In addition, Jorge Lobo’s disease has also been reported in a Brazilian woman working with infected humans and in two European human patients dealing with an infected dolphin (24, 25). Since P. loboi is restricted to Latin American countries (4), skin-infected dolphins dwelling in many oceans are suspected to acquire the infection while swimming around Latin American big rivers (4, 7, 16–19).

It is believed that propagules of the pathogen penetrate through small traumatic skin lesions near aquatic areas of endemicity. However, the real ecological environment of these pathogens is unknown. The disease seems to occur in apparently healthy hosts. It is quite possible that in nature,P. ceti and P. loboi could develop hyphae with propagules (perhaps conidia), like those in cultivated Paracoccidioides species, that gain entrance into the skin through traumatic lesions. Transmission of the disease from one patient to another is rare, but some cases of autoinoculation and accidental infection by physicians in contact with infected hosts have been reported (4, 24, 25). Moreover, the disease can be experimentally reproduced in mice inoculated with yeastlike cells from infected humans (26) or dolphins (27). Recent population genetic analysis suggested that P. ceti and P. loboi probably are dimorphic fungi with genetic defects in the pathways required for yeast cell transition to hyphae phenotype (8). In this scenario, both uncultivated pathogens are equipped with healthy genes to cycle in nature from hyphae to conidia to hyphae, genes required to transition from hyphae to yeast, and genes essential for yeast phenotype maintenance (8). The authors supported their arguments by quoting cases of Jorge Lobo’s disease in visitors coming to areas of endemicity in Latin America from nonendemic countries (21, 22), and experimental infection of mice by using yeast cells from infected hosts (26, 27).

figure.title: FIGURE 2 P. loboi. Histological sections stained with H&E (A) and silver stain (B) show the typical morphological features found in human patients with Jorge Lobo’s disease. P. loboi yeastlike cells are poorly stained with H&E and are observed as empty round structures surrounded by an area of granulomatous reaction. (Bar, 15 μm.) (B) The presence of abundant lemon-shape yeastlike branching cells in chains connected with slender tubes is the main feature of P. loboi in silver-stained sections. (Bar, 20 μm.) (C) A skin biopsy wet-mount preparation in 10% KOH shows numerous P. loboi yeastlike cells in long chains, some of them containing small intracellular dancing bodies. (Bar, 20 μm.)

sect1.title: Clinical Significance
sect1.para: Infections caused byP. ceti and P. loboi are rarely observed in the tropical areas of endemicity in the Americas (humans) and many oceans (dolphins) (4, 7, 16). Recent reports indicate that human cases of the disease are sporadic in the areas of endemicity and occur mainly in males. The number of cases so far reported is around 600, but its real occurrence could be higher. The disease is diagnosed in apparently healthy hosts inhabiting such areas. A genetic predisposition theory was abandoned after the finding that the number of cases in a Brazilian tribe with a high occurrence of the disease dramatically decreased when the tribe was moved to a new location (4). One common problem in the areas of endemicity is that patients with the disease do not seek medical attention until years after the initial infection, when the lesions have increased in size and spread to other skin areas. One explanation may be that the affected population is usually poor, with no access to health care, and that the lesions are rarely painful (4).

Frequently affected anatomical areas in humans are the arms, ears, back, chest, face, and lower limbs. Some investigators believe that the distribution of lesions on cooler areas of skin in humans may indicate that the pathogen does not tolerate well temperatures above 37°C. Initially, a single small (0.5 to 1.0 cm in diameter), smooth, parakeloidal skin lesion develops. Some patients complain of slight pruritus at this stage. The infection is not life-threatening and evolves very slowly, sometimes over 20 or more years (4). Usually, when patients seek medical attention, they have already developed more than one lesion. In the chronic phase, lesions are polymorphic. At least five clinical manifestations are recognized, including the typical parakeloidal type and the infiltrative, gummatous, ulcerated, and verrucous forms. However, Lacaz et al. (4) pointed out that two or more forms, including a macular type, could be found in a single patient. The differential diagnosis includes chromoblastomycosis, leishmaniasis, leprosy, neoplasia, paracoccidioidomycosis, and similar skin conditions.

sect1.title: Collection, Transport, and Storage of Specimens
sect1.para: The guidelines for the collection, processing, storage, and examination of specimens are provided inchapter 118 of this Manual. Clinical specimens collected in cases of Jorge Lobo’s disease are mostly biopsied tissues from the infected sites. Since the phenotypic features of the yeastlike cells are characteristic, and given the fact that P. ceti and P. loboi cannot be cultured, clinical specimens from the infected areas are usually fixed in formaldehyde for histopathologic evaluation.

sect2.title: Microscopy
sect2.para: In contrast to the systemic spread ofP. brasiliensis infection, P. ceti and P. loboi are typically confined to cutaneous and subcutaneous tissues. The lesions are characterized by fibrosis and granulomatous reactions, with numerous histiocytes and giant cells containing numerous yeastlike cells of these pathogens. Areas of necrosis and the presence of other inflammatory cells have been reported. When tissue is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), the typical yeastlike cell arrangement in chains is not observed. Instead, both P. ceti and P. loboi appear as oval to spherical, poorly stained cells or as round empty spaces with thick cell walls (Fig. 2A). Special fungal stains such as Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) and periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) should be used for the histopathological diagnosis of these uncultivated pathogens. With GMS, P. ceti and P. loboi yeastlike cells are dark or have the appearance of empty cells (Fig. 2B). Multiple budding yeastlike cells in chains of two or more branching cells, similar to the yeast cells observed in the infected tissue of patients infected with cultivated Paracoccidioides species (chapter 126), can be found in infected hosts. In the infected areas, the yeastlike cells are typically connected with small tubules, a feature also observed with other fungal stains such as PAS (Fig. 2B and C). The main difference between the yeast cells of uncultivated versus cultivated Paracoccidioides species is that the latter species develop variable-sized yeast cells in the infected tissues, whereas P. ceti and P. loboi always display uniformly sized yeast cells (8) (Fig. 2B and C).

To visualize the etiologic agent of the disease in humans and dolphins using direct microscopy, biopsy specimens should be cut into pieces 2 to 5 mm in diameter. One or more pieces are then placed with 1 or 2 drops of 10 to 20% potassium hydroxide (KOH) on a glass slide with a coverslip. The slide should be heated without boiling and then held for about 15 min at room temperature before microscopic evaluation. In 10% KOH,P. ceti and P. loboi yeastlike cells appear in great quantities (Fig. 2C). Cells ~2 to 12 μm in diameter and uniform in size can be found as multiple budding yeast cells, singly or as chains of three or more cells connected by tubules. In wet mounts, moving protoplasmic granules can also be detected within some of the yeastlike cells (Fig. 2C).

sect1.title: Nucleic Acid Detection
sect1.para: So far, there are no commercially available nucleic acid probes for the detection of this pathogen in clinical samples.

sect1.title: Isolation Procedures, Identification, and Typing Systems
sect1.para: Claims thatP. ceti and P. loboi have been isolated in pure culture have not yet been validated (4, 27). Most of the recovered organisms were fungal contaminants or P. brasiliensis (4, 10). The identification of the etiologic agent is based on the clinical features and the phenotypic characteristics on wet-mount preparations and/or histopathological analyses of the infected tissues. No typing systems for this organism exist at this time. In-house molecular procedures using suspected tissue, targeting the internal transcriber spacers (ITS) by using universal primers (ITS1 and ITS4) and sequencing used by many (13, 15), must be performed to authenticate histopathological findings (10, 20, 27).

sect1.title: Serologic Tests
sect1.para: One major obstacle to developing serologic assays has been the lack of cultures. Thus, most of the serologic approaches in humans and dolphins have been carried out using parasitic forms in infected tissues as antigen or using cultures of closely related pathogens (4). These tests showed that P. ceti and P. loboi possess cross-reactive antigens in common with fungal pathogens such as Blastomyces dermatitidis, Histoplasma capsulatum, and cultivated P. brasiliensis (4). Mendoza et al. (28), using antigenic proteins derived from the yeastlike cells of L. loboi from experimentally infected mice, found that the antibodies in the sera of humans, dolphins, and mice with the disease detected a 193-kDa immunodominant protein. Although antibodies in these sera did react with a P. brasiliensis purified gp43 antigen (28), they did not detect the corresponding gp43 homologous antigen of P. ceti and P. loboi parasitic stages. This finding suggests that the 193-kDa protein of the uncultivated pathogens may have epitopes in common with gp43 of P. brasiliensis. It also implies that, although the 193-kDa antigen expressed during human and dolphin infection cross-reacts with the antibodies against gp43 of P. brasiliensis, it might be an entirely different antigenic protein. The role of the 193-kDa P. ceti and P. loboi antigenic protein in the pathogenesis of the disease is under investigation. The use of P. loboi antigens in serological surveys to study the epidemiology of Jorge Lobo’s disease has been suggested (28). Although serology is not commercially available, the Biomedical Laboratory Diagnostics Program at Michigan State University has developed a Western blot assay that can be requested at https://bld.natsci.msu.edu/research/pythium-insidiosum/.

sect1.title: Antimicrobial Susceptibilities
sect1.para: Although antifungal therapy has cured some human cases of the disease,P. loboi is well known for its resistance to antimicrobial drugs, including most antifungals (4). This fact has left clinicians with only one choice: surgery. Due to the intractability of this organism to culture, susceptibility testing is not possible.

sect1.title: Evaluation, Interpretation, and Reporting of Results
sect1.para: Deep skin scrapings and tissue biopsies from human and dolphins suspected of skin disease due to uncultivatedParacoccidioides species should be submitted to the laboratory. The samples must be processed as described above (see “Direct Examination” and “Microscopy”) and evaluated for the presence of uniform yeastlike cells connected by small tubules forming short chains. Because P. brasiliensis in the parasitic phase forms yeast cells connected by tubules, the significant variation in size could be used to separate P. ceti and P. loboi from cultivated dimorphic Paracoccidioides species. The latter pathogen tends to develop large and small yeast cells in the infected tissues, whereas P. ceti and P. loboi yeastlike cells have a uniform size. In addition, the lack of fungal growth in culture could also be used as an aid in the diagnosis of these uncultivated pathogens. After laboratory evaluation of the clinical material, the presence of uniform yeastlike cells that yield no fungal growth in culture is used to confirm paracoccidioidomycosis ceti or paracoccidioidomycosis loboi. This is particularly important for patients from nonendemic areas who have visited areas where the disease is prevalent. The report of the results should include the finding of uniform yeastlike cells connected by tubules, the lack of fungal growth in culture, and the histopathological results of the evaluated clinical specimens.

sect1.title: Taxonomy
sect1.para: P. insidiosum was first reported more than 150 years ago in Indonesian equines (3), but successful isolation of this organism in pure culture was not possible until the beginning of the 20th century. Later, a similar organism was isolated again from horses, and the name Hyphomyces destruens was introduced. The finding that a strain from New Guinea (29) developed zoospores suggested that this pathogen was an organism in the genus Pythium. De Cock et al. (3) introduced the binomial P. insidiosum, and according to the current classification of eukaryotes, this pathogen was placed within the SAR (for “stramenopiles, alveolates, and rhizaria”) supergroup (Fig. 1) (30). Phylogenetic studies (31, 32) showed that P. insidiosum isolates from around the world cluster according to their geographic origin. Thus, it is likely that P. insidiosum could be a phylogenetic complex of closely related species, or perhaps a complex of different strains belonging to a single species, P. insidiosum (33). In addition, at least three cases of cutaneous and systemic human pythiosis caused by Pythium aphanidermatum have been reported (34).

sect1.title: Description of the Agent
sect1.para: P. insidiosum can be readily isolated on most mycological media (3). This pathogen develops white submerged colonies with a characteristic radiate pattern and few or no aerial hyphae, very similar to the mammalian pathogenic Lagenidium spp. (Fig. 3A). The hyphae have perpendicular lateral branches measuring 4 to 10 μm in diameter and possess few cross-septa (Fig. 3B). Zoosporogenesis (development of zoospores) is possible only in water cultures containing various ions, including Ca2+ (3, 35, 36). The structures in which the zoospores develop are termed vesicles (Fig. 3C).

In water culture, zoospores form by progressive cleavage and mature inside large vesicles (20 to 60 μm in diameter) (Fig. 3C). Once fully formed, the biflagellate zoospores mechanically break the sporangial wall, swim, and then encyst. In wet cultures, the zoospores have a bean-shaped phenotype with two laterally inserted flagella. It has been proposed that the zoospores may be the infectious units due to their chemotaxis motility toward open skin (35). Zoospores are kidney-like in shape, and two unequal flagella arise from inside a lateral groove. Upon encystment, the zoospores lose their flagella and become spherical. Under the right conditions, the encysted zoospores develop a germ tube and form long filaments (35). P. insidiosum oogonia (sexual stage) have rarely been observed and are believed to represent a resistant stage in nature (Fig. 3E).

sect1.title: Epidemiology and Transmission
sect1.para: Infections caused by this hydrophilic pathogen have been recorded in tropical, subtropical, and some temperate areas of the world. In the Americas, pythiosis is common in tropical Central, North, and South America, with most cases reported in Brazil, Colombia, Costa Rica, the United States, and Venezuela (3, 35). In the United States, infections are more prevalent in animals and humans inhabiting southern states, such as Alabama, Georgia, Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, and Texas. However, cases of the disease have also been reported in states farther north, including California, Illinois, Indiana, Kansas, New Jersey, Missouri, Tennessee, and Virginia, and as far north as Wisconsin and New York. In Asia, pythiosis has been reported in Japan, India, Indonesia, Pacific islands, South Korea, and Thailand and in nearby areas such as Australia, New Guinea, and New Zealand. Tropical Africa is ideal for pythiosis; however, only one case, in a dog with the cutaneous form, was reported, in the northwest African country of Mali. This might suggest that the disease has been misdiagnosed in this geographic region (31).

Until recently, infections caused byP. insidiosum were considered exotic. The disease was believed to be restricted to animals in tropical regions with few or no occurrences in other geographical areas. Interestingly, in the past 10 years, the number of pythiosis cases has increased on all continents (3, 33). The finding that humans (32–40), dogs (41, 42), and other animals can be infected indicates that previously pythiosis may have been erroneously diagnosed as a fungal infection. Most cases of pythiosis occur in apparently healthy humans and animals. In Thailand, however, the disease in humans is associated with thalassemia or similar blood disorders (38).

figure.title: FIGURE 3 (A) Colony of Pythium insidiosum on SDA showing a submerged colony with few aerial mycelia. (B) Slender, sparsely septate hyphae without fruiting bodies from culture. (Bar, 15 μm.) (C) Vesicles of P. insidiosum containing numerous unhatched zoospores. (Bar, 30 μm.) (D) Purple Medium (VPM) showing sucrose-positive P. insidiosum yellow colonies in primary isolation from biopsied tissue. (E) The development of oogonia in P. insidiosum is a rare event. The panel shows P. insidiosum oogonium from corn meal agar. (Bar, 10 μm.)

sect1.para: The infection is acquired afterP. insidiosum propagules enter the skin or the intestinal tract through traumatic lesions (35, 42). The infection is believed to be acquired from wet environments. Supabandhu et al. (43), Presser and Goss (44), and Rujirawat et al. (45) cultured and identified P. insidiosum from environmental samples, confirming the presence of this oomycete in wet agricultural environments in Thailand and the United States. In addition, cases of pythiosis in the absence of water suggest that P. insidiosum can cause infection after contact with resting spores from terrestrial environments. The transmission of P. insidiosum from one individual to another (human or animal or vice versa) has not been recorded. Only rabbits seem to be susceptible to experimental inoculation (46).

sect1.title: Clinical Significance
sect1.para: The clinical manifestations of pythiosis vary according to the infection site. Most patients with the disease state that they had a skin injury prior to the infection. The lesions caused byP. insidiosum in humans can be classified into superficial infections (keratitis); cutaneous and subcutaneous forms, including orbital pythiosis; and vascular forms that usually lead to systemic infection and death. Keratitis caused by P. insidiosum is similar to that caused by fungi and other etiologic agents (47–49). It begins with trauma to the superficial layers of the eye, followed by the development of conjunctivitis, photophobia, corneal ulcers, and hypopyon (pus in the anterior chamber of the eye). Cutaneous and subcutaneous infection is characterized by the formation of granulomatous plaques and/or ulcerated swellings that remain localized. Once the pathogen has reached the subcutaneous tissues, itchy papules may develop. The orbital form of subcutaneous pythiosis is rare and has been observed mainly in children in Australia and the United States (50). Vascular pythiosis starts with a traumatic lesion, usually on the lower limbs, followed by dissemination of the pathogen to the nearby arteries (37, 38). Initially, the infected skin shows signs of dry gangrene, and the formation of painful necrotic ulcers in some patients has also been reported (37). Clinical symptoms are pain caused by too little blood flow in the affected limb usually during exercise, local ischemia, swelling, and the absence of the dorsalis pedis pulse. As the infection progresses, an ascending arteritis, with the formation of thrombi and aneurysms of the large arteries, is the main feature. If not treated, P. insidiosum may spread through the arteries and reach the iliac and renal arteries and abdominal aorta, causing disseminated pythiosis. This form of pythiosis is more common in Thailand among patients with thalassemia, and it is usually life-threatening (37, 38, 40). Human pythiosis should be differentiated from arteriosclerosis, diabetes mellitus, Lagenidium spp. cutaneous leishmaniasis, mycotic keratitis, subcutaneous tuberculosis, subcutaneous mucormycosis, and other mycoses associated with filamentous fungi.

sect1.title: Collection, Transport, and Storage of Specimens
sect1.para: The clinical specimens required for diagnosis of pythiosis vary according to the infected host and the clinical form (32, 37). The collection, transport, and storage of clinical samples from patients with infections caused by P. insidiosum are identical to those for samples from patients with Lagenidium spp. A portion of the small tissue samples used for microscopy can also be used to inoculate Sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA) plates. The pieces should be submerged into the agar and incubated at 37°C for 24 to 48 hours. Lagenidium spp. that are pathogenic for dogs, cats, and humans develop white-yellowish, flat, glabrous colonies (Fig. 4A), like those recovered in cases of pythiosis. The presence of broad, 9- to 18-μm, coenocytic hyphae displaying large spherical structures connected by short strands of hyphae is the main feature of strains recovered from dogs (Fig. 4C). A Lagenidium strain recovered recently in a case of human keratitis showed only broad, sparsely septate hyphae (51). Strains of Lagenidium displaying spherical structures connected by short strands of hyphae can be used to differentiate P. insidiosum from Lagenidium sp. (Fig. 4C); however, some mammalian pathogenic Lagenidium spp. develop only hyphae. Those cases must be investigated using molecular methods (see below). So far, there is no typing system available for Lagenidium spp.

figure.title: FIGURE 4 (A) Colony of Lagenidium giganteum recovered from a dog with cutaneous lagenidiosis on SDA. L. giganteum develops cream to white submerged colonies at 25 and 37°C. (B) L. giganteum on Purple Medium (VPM) showing a sucrose-negative colony, a typical feature of the genus on this medium. (C) Microscopically, ribbon-type hyphae highly constricted at septa are observed in samples from SDA plates. In lactophenol blue stain, the presence of large spherical and oval structures is common in some isolates. However, some strains may develop only hyphae. (Bar, 45 μm.) (D) A 10% KOH preparation from biopsied tissue depicting several broader hyphal elements without septa. (Bar, 15 μm.) (E) L. giganteum broad hyphal elements can be observed on Giemsa-stained biopsied tissue. (Bar, 15 μm.) (F) L. giganteum vesicle still attached to the sporangial tube containing numerous zoospores from water cultures. (Bar, 25 μm.)

sect1.para: For patients with keratitis due toP. insidiosum, scrapings of the affected eyes should be collected. Dryness of clinical specimens from keratitis patients could prevent the microscopic detection of the hyphal elements and subsequent culture of P. insidiosum or Lagenidium spp. Although swabs are not recommended, if collected they must be immediately transported at room temperature in tubes with high humidity (or containing 100 μl of sterile distilled water) to the laboratory and should be processed upon arrival. The collected eye scrapings should be placed in small aseptic petri dishes and immediately transported at room temperature to be processed promptly upon arrival. Biopsy or necropsy samples are usually collected in sterile distilled water and transported at room temperature to the laboratory. Specimens collected from patients with cutaneous, subcutaneous, vascular, and disseminated pythiosis can also be placed in tubes containing sterile distilled water plus 100 U of penicillin/ml and 0.25 mg of streptomycin or 0.4 mg of chloramphenicol per ml. If these antibiotics are not available, the use of sterile distilled water is encouraged. Although some studies indicate that transportation or storage at 4°C of specimens from patients suspected of pythiosis did not interfere with the isolation of the pathogen in the laboratory, others report a considerable reduction in the number of positive cultures from samples stored at 4°C (32, 35). Consult chapter 118 of this Manual for more information on collection.

sect2.title: Microscopy
sect2.para: Clinical specimens ofP. insidiosum in 10% KOH characteristically show the presence of long (4.0 to 9.0 μm in diameter), hyaline, sparsely septate hyphal structures (Fig. 5A). Some hyphal elements may reach more than 15 μm as lateral branches at a 90° angle, a typical feature of this oomycete. P. insidiosum hyphal elements can also be colored with Giemsa (Fig. 5B) and Gram stains. In the latter stain, P. insidiosum develops Gram-positive hyphae (Fig. 5C). In histopathological preparations stained with H&E, P. insidiosum appears as short or long, hyaline, coenocytic (without septa) hyphae 6 to 10 μm in diameter (Fig. 5D). P. insidiosum’s hyphae are detectable by H&E, and thus the wide-ranging diameter of the slender hypha of the pathogen is used to differentiate this oomycete from the hyphal elements developed by members of the order Enthomophthorales (genera Basidiobolus and Conidiobolus). In infected tissues, P. insidiosum triggers eosinophilic granulomas with giant cells, mast cells, and other inflammatory cells (Fig. 5D). The hyphal elements of P. insidiosum are found in the center of microabscesses, with numerous eosinophils that usually degranulate over the organism’s hyphae (Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon) (Fig. 5D, arrows). The activation of an eosinophilic inflammatory response with the Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon is a feature in common with the members of the Oomycota Lagenidum and Paralagenidium and fungi in the order Entomophthorales, from which it must be differentiated. Although most experts in the diagnosis of pythiosis agree that it is difficult to distinguish between the hyphal structures of P. insidiosum and those of the Entomophthorales, the ribbon-type morphology and the bigger size of Entomophthorales hyphal filaments could help to distinguish these fungi from P. insidiosum. P. insidiosum’s hyphal elements are well stained by GMS and appear as short or long, sparsely septate, tubular dark structures (Fig. 5E). Transversely sectioned, poorly stained (with GMS or PAS) hyphae can be also found as ring-shaped bodies.

The most important immunohistological tests for the specific identification of the hyphal elements ofP. insidiosum in infected tissues have been the peroxidase and the immunofluorescence tests (52). Because the hyphal structures of P. insidiosum are difficult to differentiate from those in the fungi, especially the Mucormycota and Entomophthoromycota, these assays have been of paramount importance for the accurate identification of this oomycete in the absence of culture. Most of these assays are available through reference laboratories for pythiosis in the United States at Michigan State University (https://bld.natsci.msu.edu/research/pythium-insidiosum) and Pan American Veterinary Laboratories (http://www.pavlab.com/) and in other countries, such as Brazil and Thailand.

figure.title: FIGURE 5 (A) Pythium insidiosum hyphal elements in 10% KOH from biopsied tissue. (Bar, 15 μm.) (B) Giemsa-stained P. insidiosum hyphae with lateral branches from a biopsied specimen. (Bar, 15 μm.) (C) Gram-positive P. insidiosum hyphal element from a biopsied specimen. (Bar, 30 μm.) (D) The Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon is observed around P. insidiosum hyphae from a case of dog subcutaneous pythiosis (arrows). (Bar, 15 μm.) (E) Silver-stained tissue showing the typical features of P. insidiosum hyphae in infected hosts. (Bar, 10 μm.)

sect1.title: Nucleic Acid Detection
sect1.para: The first molecular approach for the diagnosis ofP. insidiosum from clinical specimens was carried out on a patient with keratitis (47). The hyphal elements present in the specimen were identified by sequencing part of the 18S rDNA region using the NS1 and NS2 and internal transcriber spacer (ITS) universal primers. This approach has been successful on clinical specimens (39, 47). Grooters and Gee (53) introduced a PCR technique for the specific identification of P. insidiosum from cultures and from clinical specimens. A set of primers (PI-1 and PI-2) that amplified 105 bp of the ITS-1 region of P. insidiosum were tested. These primers have been used by several laboratories (39) and were entirely specific when tested against several filamentous fungi. Schurko et al. (54) introduced a dot-blot hybridization technique by constructing a 530-bp species-specific DNA probe for the detection of P. insidiosum. This DNA probe specifically binds to the intergenetic spacer 1 (IGS1) of this pathogen, and it did not hybridize with the genomic DNA from 23 other Pythium species, Lagenidium gigantum, or several pathogenic fungi, including the Entomophthorales fungi Conidiobolus coronatus and Basidiobolus ranarum. This probe may be ideal for the detection of P. insidiosum from environmental samples and for the specific diagnosis of pythiosis from clinical specimens from susceptible hosts. Other similar in-house molecular assays targeting different DNA genes have been suggested, but they have limited availability (55).

sect1.title: Isolation Procedures, Identification, and Typing Systems
sect1.para: In contrast with the other hydrophilic pathogens covered in this chapter,Lagenidium spp. (see below) and P. insidiosum can be cultured on various media. The most common media used for the isolation of P. insidiosum are 2% SDA and broth with or without antibiotics (see “Collection, Transport, and Storage of Specimens”), blood agar, cornmeal agar (Difco), potato dextrose agar, and nutritive agar (Difco). Biopsy or necropsy tissues and kunkers (stony, hard masses found only in horses with pythiosis) from patients suspected of having pythiosis are usually cut into small fragments 2 to 5 mm in diameter, placed into tubes containing sterile distilled water, and vigorously washed two or three times before plating. The small fragments are then physically pushed into the agar, and the plates are incubated at 25 and 37°C for 2 or more days. The relative humidity of the incubator should be enhanced by placing a beaker of water inside the chamber. Specimens that have been transported for more than 24 h can also be inoculated into tubes containing broth and then incubated at 37°C. Usually, submerged colonies surrounding the clinical specimens are detectable after 24 to 48 h of incubation (Fig. 3A) (33). On solid medium, P. insidiosum develops only sparsely septate hyphae (Fig. 3B). The appearance of P. insidiosum on SDA media was previously described (Fig. 3A and D).

P. insidiosum can be identified definitively only if the isolate develops the characteristic oogonia (sexual stage) on culture plates. The formation of oogonia, however, is extremely rare, which further complicates the final identification of this pathogen in the clinical setting. Given that Lagenidium spp. and P. insidiosum display identical lesions in infected mammals, the development of zoospores in water as a definitive characteristic for the identification of P. insidiosum needs to be revisited. Recently the use of Purple Medium (VPM) (Fig. 3D) was proposed to differentiate primary isolation of oomycetes such as Pythium spp. and Lagenidium spp. (56). In VPM, P. insidiosum develops yellow colonies against a purple background (Fig. 3D). The identification of P. insidiosum using molecular methods with isolates and clinical specimens as described above is recommended (45, 47, 53–55) (see “Nucleic Acid Detection Techniques” above). A drawback to this approach is that only a few laboratories possess these capabilities. Although the use of sugars has been evaluated to identify this pathogen in the clinical laboratory (56), there are currently no typing systems available for P. insidiosum.

sect1.title: Serologic Tests
sect1.para: Early serologic tests showed that anti-P. insidiosum antibodies could be detected in the sera of infected hosts and, thus, could be used for the diagnosis of pythiosis. The most common assays for pythiosis are agglutination, enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), immunodiffusion, and Western blotting (57). Immunodiffusion has proven to be a very specific test, with several precipitin bands, but it is too insensitive and yields many false negatives, especially when performed with sera from humans and dogs with pythiosis (58). To overcome this drawback, an ELISA and a Western blot assay were later introduced (39, 41, 57, 59–61). These assays are extremely sensitive in detecting anti-P. insidiosum IgG. However, it may cross-react with anti-Lagenidium spp. antibodies (61). Recently, an agglutination test was used for the rapid diagnosis of pythiosis. Although it proved to be a good screening test, it had a high rate of false positives and false negatives (57). The finding that antibodies in the sera of different hosts recognize different antigenic proteins when evaluated with several geographically divergent strains of P. insidiosum suggests frequent subclinical infections with multiple P. insidiosum strains (62). Recently, a rapid dry immunochromatographic test was evaluated (63). The test was able to detect anti-P. insidiosum antibodies in the sera of humans and animals with pythiosis, but its sensitivity was lower (false negatives) than that of the traditional ELISA.

sect1.title: Antimicrobial Susceptibilities
sect1.para: P. insidiosum, like the other oomycetes (including Lagenidium spp.), does not possess ergosterol in its cytoplasmic membrane. Despite this obvious contraindication, amphotericin B and other antifungal drugs that target ergosterol have been used with mixed results. For instance, two children with orbital pythiosis were successfully treated with amphotericin B in Australia (50). However, this antifungal did not have an effect in humans from Thailand with the disease (38, 40). Recently, susceptibility testing on a strain isolated from a child in Tennessee with orbital pythiosis showed the strain to have low MICs of terbinafine and itraconazole (64). Although this combination of drugs was successfully used in this case, the same combination was less effective when tested in other humans and animals. One explanation for this contradiction is the possibility that these antifungal drugs may affect pathways other than sterols. The inconsistent results with most antifungal drugs for the treatment of pythiosis have led to the use of unconventional treatments such as immunotherapy (40). Immunotherapy has been found to be effective in 55% of humans and dogs and in 70% of equines with the disease (57). In addition, some investigators have evaluated In vitro combinations of several antifungals against P. insidiosum, with promising results (52, 65–67). These studies indicate that terbinafine plus fluconazole or ketoconazole (66) or terbinafine plus amphotericin B (67) substantially reduces the In vitro growth of P. insidiosum. However, these combinations of antifungal drugs have yet to be tested in clinical cases.

sect1.title: Evaluation, Interpretation, and Reporting of Results
sect1.para: Culture is the gold standard test for pythiosis. BecauseP. insidiosum morphological features in infected tissues are identical to those displayed in wet mounts of the fungi Conidiobolus or Basidiobolus, belonging to the Entomophthoromycotina, histopathological examination of tissue sections, serological assays, and culture must be evaluated for a proper interpretation and identification of this pathogen in the laboratory. For instance, the finding of sparsely septate hyaline hyphae in a wet-mount preparation must be confirmed by culture. Moreover, serological assays such as ELISA and Western blotting could detect anti-P. insidiosum antibodies in hosts with putative clinical diagnosis of pythiosis, but they should be interpreted with caution. P. insidiosum can cause subclinical infections in humans and animals inhabiting areas of endemicity. Thus, false positives have been found in apparently healthy individuals (57). When culture is not possible, the use of molecular approaches and/or immunohistochemical (peroxidase and immunofluorescence) tests could be of help. The presence of hyaline hyphae in wet-mount preparations and in histopathology should be reported as suggestive of pythiosis, whereas positive results in culture (development of zoospores in water cultures) or positive reactions in molecular assays and/or in immunohistochemical staining tests are reported as confirmatory tests of disease. In such cases, the report of results should include the following: “Pythiosis caused by P. insidiosum confirmed by culture and supported by serological and/or molecular assays.”

sect1.title: Taxonomy
sect1.para: Until recently,P. insidiosum was considered the only member of the Oomycota causing disease in mammalian hosts (3, 32). However, in 1999, several cases of novel Lagenidium mammalian-pathogenic species causing skin infection with dissemination to blood vessels were reported (61). The genus Lagenidium comprises oomycetous species affecting lower animals, such as crabs, mosquito larvae, nematodes, and others (61, 68, 69). Because members of the oomycetes develop hypha-like elements, they were known for a long time as the “aquatic fungi” (water molds). However, they are not true fungi. Currently, Lagenidium spp. are placed within the SAR supergroup (Fig. 1) (27). Although Dick (70), using phenotypic characteristics, recently questioned the validity of this genus, current phylogenetic studies have found that an L. giganteum isolate infecting dogs clustered with L. giganteum from mosquito larvae (71, 72). This finding suggests that the classification of Lagenidium species based on morphology alone is problematic. At least three species were recently reported: L. giganteum, affecting dogs in the United States; L. deciduum (L. vilelae), affecting a cat in the United States; and L. albertoi, causing keratitis in a Thai man (72, 73). In addition, based on phylogenetic analysis, isolates previously identified as Lagenidium sp. infecting dogs were found to be a novel genus, and thus, the name Paralagenidium was introduced (73). Interestingly, the clinical features of lesions in infected dogs were identical to those found in dog lagenidiosis (69, 73).

sect1.title: Description of the Agent
sect1.para: Lagenidium species can be readily isolated in media used to recover fungi in the clinical laboratory (60, 69). This is in contrast with some of the other pathogens covered in this chapter. On SDA, Lagenidium species develop well at 37°C and more slowly at 25°C. At 37°C, they develop white-yellow submerged colonies without aerial mycelia in less than 24 hours (Fig. 4A). Based on cases studied at Michigan State University, in contrast with P. insidiosum which develops yellow colonies in VPM medium, Lagenidium spp. in this medium develops purple colonies (Fig. 4B). In these media, Lagenidium spp. develop 8- to 20-μm ribbon-type hyphae and spherical structures 20 to 45 μm in diameter (71, 72) (Fig. 4C). In liquid media, undifferentiated hyphae can develop vesicles at the tips of these structures. The vesicle increases in size as more protoplasmic material enters the vesicle, and zoospores are formed within the following 20 minutes (Fig. 4F). The species Paralagenidium karlingii and P. ajellopsis, infecting dogs; thermotolerant L. giganteum isolates from dogs (different from thermosensitive L. giganteum from mosquitoes); L. deciduum, isolated from a cat; and L. albertoi, isolated from a Thai human patient, have been reported so far as pathogens of mammals (71–73). An unpublished human lagenidiosis infection was earlier reported in the United States, but further details on the case are unavailable (68). The presence of sexual structures (oogonia) in the mammalian-pathogenic species has yet to be reported. Therefore, the identification of Lagenidum and Paralagenidium species is only possible using molecular methodologies, such as PCR and sequencing (53, 61, 71, 73).

sect1.title: Epidemiology and Transmission
sect1.para: So far, most cases of lagenidiosis in mammalian hosts have been reported in the United States (68, 69). A case of keratitis caused by a Lagenidium sp. in a Thai human patient was recently reported (51). In addition, an Australian dog case of lagenidiosis was also studied by us (unpublished data). In the United States, lagenidiosis occurs in the same areas reporting P. insidiosum infection (see below) (65, 68, 69). This includes the states bordering the Gulf of Mexico, as well as Arkansas, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Maryland, North Carolina, South Carolina, Tennessee, and Virginia, among others. Lagenidium completes its life cycle in wet environments, possibly using lower animal hosts or plants. Mammals with open skin injuries entering contaminated environments can be exposed to the zoospores developed by these species and could develop lagenidiosis. Transmission from one infected host to another has not been observed. Experimental infection in mice has been unsuccessful (57).

sect1.title: Clinical Significance
sect1.para: The organismsParalagenidium, Lagenidium, and P. insidiosum have been recognized as emerging Oomycota pathogens causing invasive superficial, cutaneous, subcutaneous, and arterial infections (33). These pathogens have also been observed to cause systemic infection. The common sites of infection in humans and animals are the cornea, gastrointestinal tract, limbs, and other anatomical areas (51, 69). Mammal-pathogenic Lagenidium species have been reported in only three geographical areas (see above), but other tropical and subtropical regions may contain these pathogenic species as well.

sect1.title: Collection, Transport, and Storage of Specimens
sect1.para: See the corresponding text in the section onP. insidiosum.

sect2.title: Microscopy
sect2.para: Small pieces of biopsy tissue cut into 5-mm blocks, scrapings of lesions in wet mounts, and cytological samples stained with Giemsa reveal the hyphal structures ofParalagenidium and Lagenidium spp. in infected tissues. In wet mounts and Giemsa stain preparations, broad 9- to 18-μm, branched, sparsely septate hyphae (broader than those in P. insidiosum) are observed in cases of lagenidiosis (Fig. 4D and E). Differentiation in histopathological sections between Paralagenidium, Lagenidium, and P. insidiosum hyphae is difficult. Both trigger an eosinophilic granuloma (Fig. 6A), although Paralagenidium and Lagenidium hyphae are broader than P. insidiosum hyphae; a definitive diagnosis can be made only by culture (Fig. 4A) (see the text above for P. insidiosum) or by the use of molecular tools. Hyphal elements from coenocytic fungi (Mucormycotina and Entomophthoromycotina) are readily observed in H&E staining. However, the Oomycota are more difficult to detect with this stain (31, 35). The use of GMS stain is recommended in cases of lagenidiosis or paralagenidiosis (Fig. 6B). In culture, the microscopic features of some Lagenidium spp. causing lagenidiosis in dogs include oval and spherical structures, a morphological feature that could be used to separate these mammal-pathogenic oomycetes in the laboratory (Fig. 4C). However, there are mammal-pathogenic isolates of Lagenidium spp. that lack these features, and thus, morphology alone does not provide an unequivocal distinction between these two Oomycota microbes.

figure.title: FIGURE 6 (A) Histopathological H&E-stained tissue sample from cat infected with L. deciduum (L. vilelae). Note the eosinophilic material (Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon) around hyphae 12 to 18 μm in diameter (arrows). (Bar, 25 μm.) (B) Tissue sample from Fig. 4D, stained with GMS, showing L. deciduum broader ribbon-like hyphae. (Bar, 25 μm.)

sect1.title: Isolation Procedures, Identification, and Typing Systems
sect1.para: Vilela et al. (56) found that pathogenic Lagenidium and Paralagenidium species, including the fungal pathogens Basidiobolus, Conidiobolus, and Mucor, did not utilize sucrose in culture, whereas P. insidiosum was sucrose positive on a medium containing sucrose. These authors propose the use of this simple test (VPM) to putatively separate fungal and fungus-like pathogens in the clinical laboratory (Fig. 3D and 4B) (56). P. insidiosum and Lagenidium spp. isolation and identification procedures are discussed above.

sect1.title: Serologic and DNA Tests
sect1.para: ELISA and Western blot assays have been tested in cases of lagenidiosis in both humans and lower animals (57, 61). Although both assays detected the presence of antibodies in cases of lagenidiosis, the antigenic banding patterns observed in Western blots were very difficult to interpret, and ELISA had a strong cross-reaction with P. insidiosum antigens. Despite this limitation, the ELISA has been suggested to monitor the response to treatment because a decline in anti-Lagenidium antibodies has been demonstrated in cured cases (61). Specific primers targeting ITS genes for the identification of isolates or/and Lagenidium hyphae in biopsied tissue section have been described (57, 61). However, their specificity is not known.

sect1.title: Antimicrobial Susceptibilities
sect1.para: As previously mentioned, the oomycetes differ from the true fungi in several respects, one of which is that oomycetes lack sterols in their cytoplasmic membranes. Therefore,Pythium spp. and Lagenidium spp. are intrinsically resistant to most antifungal drugs targeting this pathway. Thus, an early and accurate diagnosis is essential for a good response in infected hosts. Several antifungals have been tested In vitro using Lagenidium isolated from humans and lower animals (65). Unfortunately, the in vivo response has shown contradictory results.

sect1.title: Evaluation, Interpretation, and Reporting of Results
sect1.para: Cases of lagenidiosis with positive culture (Fig. 4A and B) have to be evaluated by microscopy, looking for the typical structures encountered in some strains (Fig. 4C). If the strain does not display fruiting bodies, the induction of zoospores must be performed (Fig. 4F) (33, 36). The development of sporangia and biflagellate zoospores could be interpreted as proof that the isolate is an oomycete. So far, there are no reports of oomycetes as normal laboratory contaminants or normal microbiota of humans or lower animals. In addition, genomic DNA from the strain under investigation should be tested using molecular methods (see above) to further confirm the findings. The report of the case should include the following: (i) the presence of broad coenocytic hyphae in wet mounts and stained preparations from clinical samples, (ii) the development of zoospores from positive cultures, (iii) the identification of the isolate phenotypic features, and (iv) the use of DNA tools.

sect1.title: Taxonomy
sect1.para: The first two cases of rhinosporidiosis were reported in 1900 by Guillermo Rodolfo Seeber in his M.D. thesis in Argentina (1, 2). He stated that in 1896, he had found two patients with nasal polyps containing an organism similar to that reported by Posadas in 1892 (coccidioidomycosis). He also mentioned that, in 1892, Malbran had studied a case of a nasal polyp showing a spherical microbe with identical morphological features. A nasal case of rhinosporidiosis observed by O’Kinealy in 1903 in India was studied in detail by Minchin and Fanthan in 1905 (2). These investigators suggested the binomial Rhinosporidium kinealyi to identify this pathogen. In 1912, Seeber introduced the name Rhinosporidium seeberi and called attention to its priority over R. kinealyi. In 1924, Ashworth (2) stated that the genus Rhinosporidium, proposed by Minchin and Fanthan, should be adopted and that, based on the description of Seeber (2) and the name Coccidioides seeberia reintroduced by Belou, the binomial R. seeberi has priority.

The fact that this pathogen resists culture led some investigators to extreme hypotheses, recently reviewed by Vilela and Mendoza (74). The suggestion that R. seeberi is a cyanobacterium in the genus Microcystis is the most recent in a long list of similar views. This and other views have been challenged by several groups showing that morphological, cell cycle, and phylogenetic analyses all link this pathogen with the protistan eukaryotes (74). The placement of R. seeberi within the Ichthyosporea (Mezomycetozoea) came as a surprise. This group comprises orphan aquatic fish and amphibian parasites with spherical forms and endospores strikingly similar to those of R. seeberi (1, 5). Currently, this pathogen is part of the supergroup Opisthokonta (Ichthyosporea [Mesomycetozoea]) (30). By using the rDNA ITS, it was found that R. seeberi might include several species-specific strains that could represent new species (75).

sect1.title: Description of the Agent
sect1.para: This anomalous pathogen has resisted culture; thus, its morphological features are known only throughin vivo microscopic and ultramicroscopic studies (1, 2, 5). In infected tissues, R. seeberi has a complex parasitic cell cycle. It appears as multiple spherical structures known as sporangia (cysts in most mesomycetozoans) in different stages of development (Fig. 7A) (1, 74). The in vivo life cycle starts with the release of hundreds of oval or spherical endospores, 7 μm to >15 μm in diameter, from a pore developed only in mature sporangia (MS) (Fig. 7B). The endospores increase in size and progressively develop from juvenile sporangia (JS) (10 μm to >100 μm) to intermediate sporangia (IS) (100 μm to <150 μm), and then to MS (150 μm to <450 μm). The endospores are released from MS from one or more pores, and then the in vivo cycle is somehow reinitiated. Because R. seeberi resists culture, everything we know about its cell cycle is based on the phenotypic structures observed in infected tissues. Although the diameter of the sporangium has been used to identify the in vivo stages, the MS differs from other stages by the presence of well-developed endospores (Fig. 7B). The finding of mitotic figures within some sporangia in histological preparations has been mentioned (76). These authors found the nuclei within IS synchronously divide without cytokinesis. In large intermediate sporangia, a cell wall is developed around each endospore with thousands of nuclei, becoming an MS. Recently, Delfino et al. (77), using confocal microscopy and DAPI (4′,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole) staining, confirmed previous views (76) about the synchronized nature of the nuclear division of R. seeberi (Fig. 7C).

figure.title: FIGURE 7 R. seeberi. (A) H&E-stained tissue sample from a nose polyp showing mature sporangium (MS) with numerous endospores and JS of different sizes. (Bar, 500 μm.) (B) Release of endospores from a MS. Note the presence of small endospores arising from the opposite side of the exit pore, a typical feature of the genus (arrow). (Bar, 80 μm.) (C) Confocal microscopy of a tissue sample showing an immature sporangium containing R. seeberi parasitic stage, stained with DAPI and actin dyes. Note the presence of multiple nuclei (blue) within the cell and the binding of the actin probe (red) to the layer below the cell wall. (Bar, 25 μm.) Image courtesy of Delfino et al. (77). (D) Three immature sporangia observed in 10% KOH preparation from a nasal polyp of a man with rhinosporidiosis. (Bar, 20 μm.) (E) Giemsa impression smear from a dog with nasal rhinosporidiosis. An immature collapsed sporangium can be observed in the right section of the panel, with a few endospores on the left side (arrows). (Bar, 8 μm.)

sect1.title: Epidemiology and Transmission
sect1.para: Rhinosporidiosis usually occurs in most tropical and subtropical areas of the world except Australia (1). Although the infection was first recognized in Argentina, India and Sri Lanka show the highest occurrence of the disease (1, 78). Rhinosporidiosis occurs sporadically in other geographical areas, such as the Americas, Africa, Europe, and Asian countries, including the Middle East. Because some cases of rhinosporidiosis occur in dry areas, especially after sandstorms, the hydrophilic nature of this pathogen has long been questioned (1, 2, 74, 78). Based on accounts from patients with the disease, it is believed that rhinosporidiosis is acquired through contact with aquatic environments contaminated with R. seeberi, but the precise mechanism of infection from natural sources is unknown.

The finding linkingR. seeberi to aquatic pathogens of fish and amphibians (5–7, 78, 79) tends to confirm its hydrophilic nature. Most probably, this pathogen evolved from an aquatic niche, in which it still can be found, to terrestrial environments by the development of resistant spores. This is a very likely scenario, since the formation of zoospores, as in the other members of the Ichthyosporea, among which R. seeberi is phylogenetically located, has not been found (1, 2, 6, 79). The disease tends to occur as single cases, but two outbreaks of rhinosporidiosis in humans in Serbia (80) and in swans from Florida (81) have also been recorded. The resistant spores present in water and soil may gain entry through small cutaneous or mucocutaneous wounds and establish infection. Although the disease occurs in apparently normal hosts, some investigators have suggested associations with occupational and social conditions (1, 78). Little is known about the predisposing factors leading to the disease. The disease has not been induced in experimental animals, and transmission from one host to another has yet to be reported.

sect1.title: Clinical Significance
sect1.para: In addition to humans, rhinosporidiosis around the facial areas has been reported in several animal species, including cattle, cats, dogs, goats, horses, river dolphins, and birds (1, 6). In humans, the most common clinical manifestation is the formation of painless polyps usually located on mucosal areas of the nose, eye, larynx, genitalia, and rectum. Multicentric skin lesions have been also recorded (1, 78). Unusual cases affecting bones, skin, and other areas have been sporadically reported (74, 78, 82). The disease is not life-threatening, but it can cause breathing difficulties when the polyps obstruct the nose or laryngeal passages. Rhinorrhea and bleeding are common with polyps located in the nose. The slow-growing polypoidal masses are usually found as single or multiple, pedunculate (attached to the skin), sessile, red lesions that bleed easily. Pruritus of the affected areas is also common. The differential diagnosis includes bacterial and fungal infection, neoplasia, and other similar mucosal and skin conditions.

sect1.title: Collection, Transport, and Storage of Specimens
sect1.para: The guidelines for the collection, processing, storage, and examination of specimens are provided inchapter 118 of this Manual. Clinical specimens collected in cases of rhinosporidiosis are usually biopsy tissues from infected sites. Since R. seeberi cannot be cultured, clinical specimens are usually fixed in formaldehyde upon collection to be histopathologically evaluated later. Nonetheless, fresh samples should also be examined in the laboratory to rule out other etiologic agents and to confirm the histopathological findings. In these cases, biopsy specimens should be aseptically collected and transported immediately to the laboratory. For samples collected far from the laboratory, cooling (−80°C to 4°C) of collected specimens for shipping or storage purposes may be necessary.

sect2.title: Microscopy
sect2.para: Wet-mount preparations from clinical specimens from cases of rhinosporidiosis usually show the presence of mature and immature spherical sporangia and endospores (Fig. 7D and E). Mature sporangia with endospores have thin cell walls and measure more than 400 μm in diameter (Fig. 7B). JS and IS are smaller and may have thicker cell walls. In fresh specimens treated only with water, the release of endospores from MS has been reported (6). A purification system to study R. seeberi phenotypes was recently proposed (1). The presence of R. seeberi sporangia and endospores can also be detected on smears stained with Giemsa or Gram stain (Fig. 4E). The spherical unstained elements of R. seeberi develop autofluorescence when viewed with a fluorescence microscope.

The parasitic spherical structures of this mesomycetozoan pathogen stain very well with H&E (Fig. 7A), but they also stain with GMS and PAS, a feature used by many in the past to suggest a link with the members of the kingdom Fungi. Biopsy tissue from polypoidal lesions stained with H&E is characterized by the presence of numerous sporangia at different stages of development (Fig. 7A and B). Hyperplasia of the mucous membranes and/or skin with fibrovascular and fibromyxomatous connective tissue containing numerous sporangia is the main feature of the infection. Inflammatory infiltrates of lymphocytes, neutrophils, plasma cells, and, more rarely, giant cells and eosinophils are usually observed in cases of nasal, ocular, and skin infections. JS and IS possess a central nucleus with a prominent nucleolus (74, 77). The collapse of defective sporangia may cause the formation of U-shaped structures. Some MS with numerous endospores can be found near the mucosal epithelium, where they are transported from the internal infected areas by a transepidermal elimination phenomenon (Fig. 7A and B) (1, 2, 78). The cell wall of the MS is usually thin, and the enclosed endospores may contain clusters of 1- to 3-μm reddish spherical vesicles (Fig. 7B). Endospores have a mucoid capsule that does not stain in H&E preparations. The presence of a pore on the sporangial wall is also observed, depending on the plane of the sectioned tissue (Fig. 7B).

sect1.title: Nucleic Acid Detection
sect1.para: Currently, there are no available DNA-based techniques for the diagnosis ofR. seeberi.

sect1.title: Isolation Procedures, Identification, and Typing Systems
sect1.para: Despite numerous reports claiming thatR. seeberi has been isolated in pure culture, such claims have not yet been validated (74). Most of the organisms recovered from cases of rhinosporidiosis have proven to be fungal or bacterial contaminants (1, 74). Because R. seeberi has not yet been cultured, the identification of this pathogen is based on its phenotypic characteristics on wet-mount preparations and/or histopathological analyses. The morphological characteristics of R. seeberi in infected tissues are almost pathognomonic. Nonetheless, the organism’s epidemiological features and the clinical signs of disease should be taken into consideration for a final diagnosis. Morphologically, the parasitic (spherule) stages of Coccidioides immitis and Coccidioides posadasii mimic the R. seeberi sporangia with endospores and, in some ways, the spheres without endospores of Adiaspiromyces crescens. However, the sporangium size range of R. seeberi (<400 to 600 μm), the epidemiological, clinical, and phylogenetic features of coccidioidomycosis, and the fact that Coccidioides species can be readily cultured categorically separate this pathogen from R. seeberi.

sect1.title: Serologic Tests
sect1.para: Although early investigators did not detectR. seeberi antibodies in the sera of infected hosts by using endospores or sporangia as antigens, others suggested that the reason for the failure was the use of insensitive assays such as immunodiffusion. Using an immunoelectron-microscopic approach, it was shown for the first time that anti-R. seeberi antibodies react against a specific antigen in MS in the sera of patients with rhinosporidiosis (1, 78). Despite these efforts, there are no available serological diagnostic assays for rhinosporidiosis in the clinical setting.

sect1.title: Antimicrobial Susceptibilities
sect1.para: R. seeberi is resistant to most antifungal drugs (1, 78); however, the use of dapsone was found to be helpful in controlling some cases (1). Because this pathogen continues to resist culture, susceptibility testing is not possible. Treatment is carried out by surgical removal of the infected tissues, but recurrences are common (1, 76, 82).

sect1.title: Evaluation, Interpretation, and Reporting of Results
sect1.para: The finding of spherical structures at different stages of development, some of them containing numerous endospores on histopathology, in cytological samples stained with Giemsa and Gram stains and in wet-mount preparations, is suggestive of rhinosporidiosis. Since theR. seeberi spherical structures with endospores mimic the parasitic stage of Coccidioides species, a differential diagnosis is required, especially in the areas where coccidioidomycosis is endemic. The finding of >300-μm spherical sporangia with endospores and negative cultures could be confirmatory of rhinosporidiosis. The report of the results should contain the finding of typical spherical structures with endospores, structures in the infected tissues that resist culture, and molecular sequencing (if available) to confirm the phenotypic findings.
